awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Moving beyond causation: the ecological consequences of the terminal Pleistocene extinction of North American megafauna
awd_abstract_narration:
Biodiversity is being lost from ecosystems worldwide, and when it results in the loss of large-bodied species (megafauna) it can have major consequences for entire food webs, and the structure and function of those ecosystems. This study will examine a past major extinction of megafauna in order to understand the cascading effects on ecosystems. About 13,000 years ago many species of large mammals in the Americas became extinct. This research will examine the consequences of the loss of these large carnivores and herbivores from the food web to the remaining plant and animal communities. The responses seen at this long-ago event will be used to develop general concepts relevant to modern-day changes in plant and animal communities. This project will also make fossil data more easily accessible and interpretable, will improve museum collections, and will inform the public through outreach activities conducted by the Smithsonian Institution. This work will also provide graduate and undergraduate students with research experience that will strengthen the scientific workforce. 

The consequences of the loss of tens of millions of large-bodied mammals about 13,000 years ago on the structure and functioning of ecosystems in the Americas will be examined in order to address four questions: How did the extinction of large-bodied mammals influence overall community structure and species interactions at the terminal Pleistocene; Did surviving species become more abundant or change their geographic distribution; What changes in morphology, if any, occurred in species that survived the extinction; Did surviving species alter their dietary niche in response to the extinction of megafauna? Patterns of abundance, distribution, diet and morphology in the surviving mammals both before and after the extinction event will be characterized. Using occurrence information from fossil database compilations, morphology and size will be determined by measuring fossil limbs and molars, and diet by using stable isotope analysis. These data will be integrated with reconstructions of vegetative communities using pollen databases and regional and global temperature records. An important ecological baseline for the understanding of contemporary trophic downgrading will be established by characterizing how terrestrial ecosystems were influenced by humans at an important point in human history.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. This grant focused on one of humanity’s greatest challenges – how to slow down, halt, or mitigate the continued loss of biodiversity on Earth. With the exception of African savannahs and a few other regions, the world has lost much of its large animal biodiversity over the past centuries. A major focus of conservation biology is geared towards developing an synoptic understanding of how their loss may impact contemporary ecosystems; a task made difficult by long-time lags inherent in ecological interactions. Employing a deeper time perspective provides insights into the crucial role megafauna play in ecosystem function and the erosion that occurs with their loss. In our project, we used the terminal Pleistocene megafauna extinction as an analogy for understanding ongoing and future biodiversity loss. We built an unparalleled late Quaternary fossil record spanning >20,000 years by processing >43,000 fossil elements from cave sites within the Edward’s Plateau of Texas (including >35,053 newly identified and 9,395 newly accessioned fossils). We employed modeling approaches, empirical characterizations of diet through stable isotopes, and 2D/3D imaging to quantify changes in ecological function, community structure/organization, and in surviving mammals immediately before and after the terminal Pleistocene megafauna extinction. Specific findings included: the mammal community in the Edward’s Plateau was decimated by the extinction; most previously filled niches remain empty. Felidae showed the strongest ecological response, with the jaguar becoming an apex predator in the Holocene and shifting into the niche previously occupied by extinct sabertooth cats. Puma, previously absent, became common and occupied the dietary niche vacated by jaguar. Lagomorphs were the only herbivores to shift from browse to graze (i.e., towards C4 resources). Body size changes from the Pleistocene to Holocene were species-specific, with some animals (deer, hare) becoming significantly larger, and others smaller (bison, rabbits) or exhibiting no change to either climate shifts or biodiversity loss. Overall, the Holocene body size-isotopic niche was drastically reduced with considerable ecological complexity lost. Moreover, declines in functional diversity were greater than expected given biodiversity loss following both the terminal Pleistocene extinction and further historical ones, implying extinct taxa contributed higher than average ecological function. Functional distances between remaining species increased through time, leading to less functional redundancy in younger communities. Intriguingly, the introduction of exotic species such as Blackbuck, Axis deer, and Oryx in Texas has partially replaced some functional space lost at the terminal Pleistocene. We conclude biodiversity loss led to reorganization of survivors and many ‘missing pieces’ within the modern community. )ur analysis demonstrates biodiversity loss can change the function of ecosystems, leaving them functionally depauperate and less resilient to future environmental challenges.

 

Broader Impacts. Significant broader impacts arose from the conservation implications of our research and efforts curating the fossil collection. Over the course of the project, we processed >43,000 fossil elements; totals include ~9,400 newly identified fossils accessioned for TMM from fossil matrix. All photos/data were provided to TMM. Our project also included numerous outreach efforts designed to reach underrepresented student populations and the public. Our ability to advance science literacy among the public is facilitated by the inherent fascination most find with the idea that the Americas were once home to charismatic megafauna such as mammoths, llamas, camels, giant ground sloths and saber-toothed cats. 

Specific activities included: 1) Development of a diverse and competitive STEM workforce by mentoring students in interdisciplinary, team science approaches. For example, of 25 participants, 60% were female, including the PI and one Co-PI, and 44% are from underrepresented groups, including Hispanic, African American, and Native American. Moreover, diversity extends across professional ranks: the PI and all postdocs are Hispanic females, as are many grad/undergrad students. Thus far, two PhD, two Master’s, and an undergraduate honors thesis have been produced; more are in progress, 2) 19 published papers to date, including several high profile ones in Science and the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, and a textbook – Mammal Paleoecology using the past to study the present was completed, published, and is now in use in a paleoecology course developed as part of this grant. 3) Increasing public scientific literacy and public engagement with science and technology through a broad array of activities, including public talks (i.e., New Mexico Museum of Science and History, Tate Geological Museum, Carnegie Museum of Natural History, Yukon Beringia Interpretive Centre, National Museum of Nuclear Science and History, Science on Tap, etc.), and dozens of interviews with international radio, television and print venues (including the PBS Nova series), and support of  the UNM 'BioBlog', an outreach effort developed by the senior investigator that brings together undergraduate and graduate students weekly to develop and hone writing about science and to learn how to constructively critique the writing of others.
